review_title: The Best Company I've Ever Worked For!
pros: Southwest Airlines practices the element of inclusion more than any other company I've worked with. Everyone has a voice, and the element of respect is unconditionally present at all times. NO WORDS will ever describe how indebted I feel to be apart of this company. It's a priceless feeling!
cons: Honestly, there are no cons currently.

review_title: Not the job it use to be… BEWARE
job_title: Southwest Flight Attendant in Dallas-Fort Worth
pros: SWA is the largest domestic carrier in the US and is most likely not going away any time soon.
cons: Flight attendants only get paid for the actual flight time. When the airplane doors are closed. So the hourly rate, being offered only applies to that time. You get paid zero for All other required duties of the day…. Report times in advance of flights, boarding the plane, cleaning the plane after the flight, ground time between flights, weather delays, plane changes, etc.

review_title: Good benefits, pay is lacking, very difficult for new hires.
job_title: Flight Attendant in Bwi Airport, MD
pros: -Great healthcare and sick benefits -Commuter clause is the best in the industry -quarterly PIN allows sick day without occurrences. -Good company culture -Improvements here happen daily, slow progress is still progress.
cons: -Pay for new hires is not nearly enough to live on. I say this as someone who worked for a regional before this, (YX) so I've worked on salary that was less than this one. ($25/hr) -You will more than likely be relocated to a base that was not your first choice for the first 1-3 months of employment. I had to commute from BWI to OAK and it was Hell. On. Earth. No reimbursement for hotels of course, because that's the industry standard. -Reserve system is outdated and you are on call each day, for 24 hours. -Technology here is in the dumps. The bidding software needs updating. The crew scheduling software needs updating. The whole dang planes need updating. -Get used to disappointing passengers. -Wi-fi? More like Try-fi. 60% chance it doesn't work.

review_title: Just another big headache, avoid it at all cost
job_title: Affiliated Company Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: They seem to be pretty open to advice and counseling on their weaknesses. Our firm gets paid nicely to tell them what their frontline employee have already told them. Management seems like they are smart people on the outside but on the inside thats another story.
cons: They fail to recognize workflow efficiency metrics and establish a set program. Management seems to think the people they work for are robots. They fail to attract and retain talent due to company bureaucracy. Company branding and corporate has diminished in quality over the years. They seem to have an ego problem or a cult problem and seem to think they are the best. I cant help these people. Ego can destroy companies.

review_title: It depends on the area you work in, but don’t work for the HR departmen
pros: Good benefits Good CEO Good pay and bonus structure
cons: People department culture Cut in coheart flight benefits and perks Lack of employee care and recognition No collaboration Limited autonomy and independent judgement

review_title: Where there’s smoke there’s fire…Southwest has really big problems
pros: If you like to fly 737s it‘s 4-5 legs a day it’s fun but you will fly a lot for less than industry pay than even flying 737s at other airlines. I’ve been here almost 2 decades and Southwest has definitely changed, it's become worse than I would’ve ever imagined.
cons: You will work an extremely busy schedule away from home to get what your peers at other airlines get for working much less with more benefits and a better quality of life. A contract is impossible to get done and forget accurate pay audits. We have to fight for everything and our leadership talks a big game about LUV but treats us as undervalued and under appreciated cost units. The big push now is local chief pilots are harassing pilots you for using negotiated sick time. Pilots get called into the office to explain themselves. I guess they have to make up for the $1 Billion lost for bad leadership decisions. If you have a chance to work at any other airline you’ll have a better career there especially if you’re a younger pilot.

pros: Free standby air travel, good benefits, overtime available, you can give away shifts or shift trade. Down time between flight assignments can be 1-2hours of rest. Can be fun and easy at times.
cons: So much mandatory overtime you will not travel, Can be “mando’d” up to 3.75 hours every single day, hard on the body, must lift and throw 300-1000 suitcases that are 50-75 lbs while squatting/kneeling on metal for up to 11.75 hours with one guaranteed day off per week. Can be called in on your day off. Must inhale jet fuel all day. Generally dangerous and extremely demanding on the body, high injury rates.

review_title: Average airline with no class to board
pros: When we started the job was pretty productive and laid back. 401K is industry leading.
cons: Now the work environment is pretty toxic. Some of those clowns in the IT department decided on making decisions that cost the company billions. Now we have to fix their mistakes. Not only is it counterproductive but all those years we spent fixing an existing system was for nothing. I've witness since I been here countless mistakes and the managers keep getting promotions. At other places they would be fired for their incompetence. I guess the shareholders should really consider investing in another airline. I've since moved on to working with another airline in the "Big Four" its just not with Southwest. This was the best thing I could have ever done for myself, my family and my health.

job_title: Associate Technology Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Southwest Airlines is an amazing company with rich culture. Everyone is supportive and welcoming personally and professionally. I feel valuable as an employee. The company is open to feedback to improve with action items.
cons: 100% remote is convenient but makes collaborative work challenging to align. I am doing other responsibilities than what I was hired for. A reorganization would help with creature structure for productivity.

pros: - Competitive pay and benefits - Great teams - Fleixble schedules (for now, but never guaranteed) - Great career mobility options - Great brand
cons: - Failure to think critically about remote work and its potential - Pretentious upper leadership - worsening every year (RIP to Herb K.) - Extremely disorganized behind the scenes - Upper leaders creating a new fear-based, fake culture that is replacing the old real culture - No trust in Employees

review_title: Fun but away from home a lot
pros: Great people. Fun atmosphere. You can be yourself.
cons: You're away from home a lot and the work can be lonely because you rarely work with the same person twice.

pros: Truly wonderful people work here. Good benefits, medical coverage, etc. Flight benefits are awesome, of course. Salary is fine, but it could always be better. Lots of fun culture events (for anyone who likes that kind of thing) and there's also really great company swag.
cons: Mediocre amount of PTO (and there is a policy that you cannot use any time off unless you have accrued it, which is tough on new employees; different from other businesses that allow you to borrow against your total yearly PTO) Frustrating "in-person is best" mentality: even after an employee survey showed that workers were happy with their remote work options and flexibility, the company STILL decided to change their work from home policy to mandate that 3 days a week must be in-office.

job_title: Flight Attendant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very flexible work schedule if you have seniority in position. Contract is among best in industry.
cons: Many years with stagnant wages. Company is consistently slow to negotiate new contracts. Workload always increasing with no increase of pay. Poor morale within department due to ongoing labor disputes and general feeling that we are under compensated. Management used to have our trust, now most employees are mistrustful of anything the tell us. Decades of technology failures and underinvestment in mobility and tech enhancements make our jobs much more difficult compared to peers at other airlines. Benefits have gotten worse every year for decades, slow and steady decline in overall benefit package.

pros: You can get thrown into some stuff
cons: They love their culture If you don’t, it’s awkward Not really remote remote jobs

review_title: Not a bad airline to work for
job_title: Flight Attendant in Bwi Airport, MD
pros: In need of some changes, but overall a great airline. Nice layovers and opportunity to make good money,
cons: Long days and short layovers.

job_title: Flight Attendant in Bwi Airport, MD
pros: 401k, profit sharing, Cohearts/Team members
cons: The lack of transparency. Don’t believe the hype! They spend hundreds of thousands on Company parties yet refuse to update their employees contracts. Blame the employees for lack of updated technology. Their creative at receiving free labor yet claim that their employees matter while they can barely afford to live independently due to inflation and the lack of a updated contract.

review_title: Company leadership seems to hate the pilots
pros: If you're willing to work more you can make more money. Schedule flexibility is pretty good after the first few years. Some of the base chief pilots and base coordinators are AWESOME and do everything they can to support the pilots.
cons: Upgrade to Captain is still several years longer than at other airlines. Only one aircraft type with below-industry pay rates. Career earnings opportunity is several million below other airlines. The company's hiring plan is to keep hiring until they don't have to offer premium overtime rates any longer (fact check - it's the last question in 1Q 2022 earnings call), which pretty much kills one of the 2 pros of flying for Southwest, ie. the ability to earn more by working more. Repeated operational meltdowns that are largely due to outdated scheduling and operational policies and processes, but blamed on weather and technology. After the last huge operational meltdown that cost the company over $800 Million, not one executive, manager, or leader was fired. Instead, there were promotions and multi-million dollar executive bonuses immediately afterwards.

pros: The flight privilege's are always a plus.
cons: The seniors bully the new hires. Management allow it due to them being friends with the seniors. The mandatory overtime. THE PAY is not conducive to today's inflation.

pros: The employees are the best I have ever met. Fun environment. 401k match, profit sharing, low health insurance premiums, Inclusion Servant Leadership
cons: Siloes among departments and finger-pointing of other departments. An attitude of you other departments need to improve but we are doing everything perfectly. Heavy politics in Technology departments Often oppressive workload "Policies" are loosely followed. They are more suggestions. All companies have areas for improvement. SWA has its problems but is still one of the best places to work in the World.

review_title: Still the best gig I will ever have.
pros: The people are what makes this the best job in the world.
cons: Still working through some tech challenges.

review_title: Solid Compensation. Good team culture, but some stress showing between departments

pros: Team culture. Compensation. Flight benefits. Company growth.
cons: Divisions between departments is growing. DEI and ESG are creating us vs. them mentality. Need to better focus on the basics that built SWA over the first 45 years.

review_title: Lack of management accountability, inadequate focus on labor contracts
pros: Retirement match, 401K, medical/dental, overtime
cons: Years of delays in contract negotiations, impact of inflation on wages, $850 million loss 2022 Q4 affecting profit - sharing with employees, shifting blame for tech and ops failures, poor morale

pros: Flight Benefits No minimum or Maximum Hours Monthy Line Bidding, Overlap=time and a half. No PBS Bidding

pros: We have such flexibility at SWA. Work as much or as little as you wan/need. It’s great for those who really need some time off to assist with family matters without the added stress of wondering if you will have a job upon your return. We have a wonderful culture where you are encouraged to be your genuine self and not some cookie cutter version of a Ken and Barbie. Our passengers LUV that! Lots of opportunities to move throughout the company.
cons: Like any airline, seniority is everything. Please be aware that when you first start, you will be at the bottom of the seniority list. That means you are most likely to be on reserve, work weekends and/or holidays, and start at a lower pay rate. But with our flexibility you are able to trade with other flight attendants to get the schedule you need.

review_title: its ok but not what I expected, there are better places
pros: Starts out ok, 401K is good but with any companies its 5 years till you fully vested, heal benefits coud be better. Some little perks
cons: They give you two weeks of paperwork training and no gen fam until you made it past probation. Daily activities include, bringing in food for senior mechanics, cleaning up their garbage, give them massages and warm their feet, and be the company's janitor when you not busy. If you do make it past probation through the cliches, you will feel a sense of accomplishment but dont let that fool you. You will go on the grind everyday, they call it "production" where you are at. After a couple of years you realize that there are places that pay better and have a more comfortable work environment, getting treated with dignity and respect. They also start you out higher than when you started here. Theres a saying, if your mechanics is out working all night, its not a good sign for your airline. I've since moved on to better opportunities, got a job with UPS, a little less pay than here but I can't complain, free health insurance and I will probably make more than If I had stayed long term. It was the best decision in my life after working here and realizing what the industry has to offer. I am glad southwest gave me the chance to grind and bleed, it built my character and gave me better opportunities. I pass it along my peers now, don't complain there are poor mechanics out there that take a beating every night, we got it good here.

Once hired, the restrictions to stay as hired (no transfer or promo attempt or restricted) is where you stay) I loved and was proud to work for SWA, but when it became just like Frontier or Spirit, I left. review_title: Started strong and the culture has diminished every year…

cons: The corporate culture is waning. The company talks a big talk then gives themselves a bonus, a promotion, stock buybacks and special items to limit adding to profit sharing and rewarding frontline workers. Technology is 20 years, 20,000 employees, and 500 aircraft behind where it should be. (Spent the money on bonuses…for the C Suite) The cookie is crumbling from the top down. Public perception is all that remains. That will be gone soon and that as they say is that. Pilots are voting for a strike. Southwest is officially any other airline out there.

review_title: Outside is PRETTY & Inside is UGLY!
pros: 1.) Great 401k match. 2.) Great benefits. - Medical, Dental, Vision, etc. 3.) Schedule flexibility.
cons: 1.) Leadership is “tone deaf” to its frontline employees. 2.) Leadership is extremely “old school.” 3.) No diversity within upper management. 4.) Long days and short overnights. Too many legs. 5.) Flying on a Boeing 737. 6.) Working on a outdated and expired contract. 7.) Very underpaid for all the work you do. 8. ) Outdated technology. 9.) The Herb Culture is invisible. 10.) No growth opportunities. 11.) Horrible travel benefits 12.) No LUV

pros: I’ve had mostly good experiences with my working crews. Everyone is very welcoming and helpful.

review_title: Ok for regional mechanic upgrade, not a real major airline by any means
job_title: Aircraft Maintenance Technician in Denver, CO
pros: Well some people work well with each other, 401K is generous, ok health
cons: After going thru their 2 weeks of paperwork course with no "gen" fam class until you are done with probation, you get to experience what it feels like to figure it out on your own. Play hunger games, hint you aint getting a lunch break. Some leads will exercise some judgement and give mechanics with less experience a lighter load. Not all work is created equal, come here from another major / legacy and they will give you two times the work load. You either got to suck it up, and take it or quit on probation, look at them the wrong way and you will be singled out. If you do end up staying, by the end of the decade you will wish you never wasted that much time here. With worker shortage, do not come here thinking its the "best" in the industry, all that is PR trash department that promotes a philosophy of brain washing people who dont know industry standard work conditions are. Majority of the reviews are made from contractors the company hires to write. You get to do work that other real majors do with 2x more man power. So you get a couple of dollars extra higher than those major but is it worth blowing your knees or damaging your back? Furthermore, all that 401K you saved by the end of your career will be used on surgery to recover your broken body and chemical laced skin. hint, you aint gonna enjoy the fruits of your labor, the company has a formula they use to calculate to save money, hence they never laid off a single worker, all of them quit or broken enough body parts to be eligible for disability. I am glad I made a move and left early before hearing the same stories from other former Southwest employees, went straight to UPS best decision ever. They get paid more, work load is not ridiculous, and actually go to lunch breaks and benefits that blows southworst off the charts.

job_title: Customer Service Agent in Denver, CO

cons: Pay is abysmal, the Union will take even more money from you. What would be considered as a "rewards program" has been stunted to become an electronic way to say, "Thank you" with any kind of bonus or reward handed out by the company directly.
Multiple rules and regulations to stunt your advancement or movement within the company leaving you with few options to do so.
Union contract negotiations.
Mandatory overtime and extensions.
The culture is tough as much of the attitude I've come across has been, "Someone else will take care of it". This makes working very tough as this attitude at other locations WILL affect you at any given time.
Work load doesn't seem fair at times with some giving more work than others.
Union contract gives us the benefit of seniority but with so many rules surrounding that benefit, it can get muddled and difficult to understand at times leaving us feeling as though seniority isn't being followed when it comes to being handed any kind of mandatory overtime.

pros: Southwest is a great place to work. The culture is one of the best in the industry. I met more friends in my short time there compared with longer tenures at other airlines. People really look out for each other, as it is unionized. Flight benefits. Great place to get your foot in the door if you’re planning for a career in the airline industry, as opportunities to move up and around the system are endless.
cons: Micromanagement is a problem; plenty of jobs that exist that are more consolidated with other airlines. The union is a blessing and a curse; they are a really big help, as some management leaders are hired out of desperation and are rushed into their position without being thoroughly trained in all aspects of what they are to supervise/manage (people with no airline experience should go through at least 6 months of being a ramp agent to get a grasp that this industry is not like other jobs), leading to very few standard protocols that carry over between different stations and questionable management and supervisory decisions at work that are constantly checked and balanced by the union. The union can be a curse, as pay rate changes aren’t across the system, as the union is the factor halting it and other changes from being more streamlined and immediate, there are many people that have an “entitled” mentality, employing a minimal effort approach to work, and, of course, union dues. Southwest is a primarily domestic airline, so flight benefits are mainly in the U.S. and a small number of Caribbean destinations. Mandatory overtime on your first day off and extensions are to be expected for at least six months from when you start, due to inadequate staffing. Do not expect a 9 to 5 schedule, with weekends and holidays off, when you first start. Some work systems/tools are behind compared to other airlines.

review_title: Great Company, but Expanding Way too Fast
job_title: Pilot Training Scheduler in Dallas, TX
pros: Amazing flight benefits and wonderful company to work for. Even amidst current industry struggles, Southwest is still a beloved airline, and there is a very good reason for that.
cons: The company is trying very hard to expand our pilot base at a rapid pace. We do not currently have the qualified instructor staffing for this to be easy, so our schedulers (myself included, even after only working there for a year) are WAY burned out. Working overtime is almost a constant request from leadership, and a lot of our concerns seem to go unheard by our immediate supervisors in a meaningful way. There seems to be a focus of micromanaging the schedulers instead of providing us with some kind of relief of the volume of training that we are having to figure out. Also, a lot of the computer programs that we use every day are clunky and outdated, making many of our processes incredibly manual and tedious. We still have an entire room dedicated to paper filing, for goodness' sake.

pros: The people are what make Southwest special. Work-life balance is great as well. The flight benefits, retirement, and 401k match are world class. Executive leadership is great too. Gary Kelly did a fantastic job navigating the company through the pandemic. The company is in great hands with Bob Jordan as the new CEO. The low cost structure has set the company up for long term success even during and after the pandemic. The company has values that make employees feel like assets instead of a cost.
cons: Mid-management politics can be a little challenging to navigate at times. There seems to be a "what's in it for mentality?" when you are trying to work with other teams. Strategy is not always driven with data which can put strain on the analytic teams at times. The company has tried to implement steps to mitigate these though steering committees and prioritization meetings with leadership. It's issues that are known and they are activity trying to take steps to improve.

cons: Less flexibility because they do not have the necessary staffing to manage the operation so a lot of mandatory overtime is being given out, which pays double time but gets exhausting. Working with a lot of lazy coworkers who are looking to do as little work as possible and complain when asked to do the normal level of work. Not only not enough staffing but management has began sending equipment to other airports so now equipment is not available to properly run the operation.

job_title: Customer Service Support in Dallas, TX
pros: Free flights, tons of opportunity for growth/movement
cons: Understaffed, too much MOT, out of union contract currently

pros:
Meeting new people, helping customers and feeling good when you can make their day. Letting the flight attendants and pilots know about a special customer (we had an older lady finish college and it was her bday. Her and her husband were celebrating, so we made the announcement so the gate knew with cheers and congratulations from most and the FA and staff on-board the plane handle in the fun afterwards.)
You go to Dallas for a week of training and that was fun and very interesting. The job itself isn't hard. The trainers you click with, stay with them. You will meet some of the uppers in management- they always smile and talk. Always nice and enjoyable to chat with.
cons:
Drama is like high school- everyone talks about everyone. Customers are allowed to hit you and such, you can't fight back. Probation for csa is 7 months long and can only have 3 occurrences (call outs) til you're fired. Doctors notes are accepted but will still count as an occurrence while on probation. You may be scheduled to train in International but if no trainers available, you will put someplace else and you may find out where hours later after waiting in the breakroom. You may get told to go find so and so (you have no clue who these trainers are or what they look like) at where ever they are, go there and the trainer be like "I don't feel like training today and only wanted the parking spot" so then you have to go back to the office.. 
It is a union job. You pay union dues but told you can't meet your rep til after your probation is done. You pay for parking to take a shuttle. While that isn't bad, I've been paying 64 a month for that when it is supposed to be 32.. the 1800 incentive is 75 bucks on your paycheck taxed out to hardly anything. You need to wait 6 months til you can move around with no points or occurrences. No vacation time but you get fto days while need to be put in 24 hours in advance. While you can fly non rev (free) anywhere there is NO guarantee you will get a flight out or back- use the app wisely when looking at seating even 33 open seats can full up rather quickly in a few hours.

pros:
-401k matches dollar for dollar at up to 9% of paycheck
-double pay for mandatory overtime
-low-costing health benefits with good coverage
-anual profit shares usually at least a few thousand dollars
-learn multiple functions, so not always doing the same thing
-MSP is a small station, so there's plenty of downtime to rest in between flights 
-well organized work system and helpful co-workers
cons:
-Mandatory overtime is the main drawback. It's assigned by seniority, so when you're new it will suck for a while. Depending on the busyness of the season or call-offs or flight delays, you may have to come in early, stay late, get forced to work your first day off and even have to work an additional shift in between your regular shifts (the last one is only if things are really bad). It will happen during winter and spring break, but it typically gets better after the first year, so I've heard (but MSP hasn't been hiring since Covid hit, so it's going to be a lot longer for me). The double pay is nice, but it's impossible to plan anything outside of work when you don't know for sure if you're going to have time off throughout the week. Again, it's only really bad during those busy seasons and it does get better (at least at MSP), but it can be incredibly frustrating. You either need to get shifts covered or trade shifts or call in sick and finesse the system when they're screwing you over too much.
-Senior agents who have it made constantly complain about stupid stuff while you're getting screwed over.

pros: I was hired in 2001 after 9/11 was at another airline and very unhappy there and poor. I made more money at Southwest in my first month than I ever did in the 1.5 yrs at the previous airline. I’m happier here at Southwest than I ever was at my previous airline. I don’t work any harder than I did there a miss conception people have. Biggest plus is I make a lot more money than my classmates from my previous airline $$$
cons: We don’t have International flights only near-International flights Mexico and the Caribbean.

pros:
*Flight benefits with Southwest and nearly all other airlines worldwide.
*The most generous company 401k match I've ever heard of. 
*Profit Sharing
*Fun-loving work atmosphere!
*Generous yearly wage raises and cost of living adjustments!!
*The physical work as a ramp agent is pretty easy once you learn the routine. Team-work and safety-mindedness is always required!
*Employee rewards program- we earn points monthly that can be redeemed for anything imaginable (visa gift cards, buddy passes, literally any physical item (Kitchen. Electronics, tools..) can be "purchased."
* Your hardwork is recognized.
* We're encouraged to move around. Open new stations, switch job positions - we hire from within first! Many coworkers have gone to headquarters for careers or became Flight Attendants.
* Union shift differential pay monthly - you earn between $80 all the way up to $255 monthly based on shift time start and finish throughout a shift bid.
* Union time off (vacation) is good. Including a free paid day off every month (floating holidays) to line up with your 2 days off or whenever you bid for.
* Union.
* Too many other benefits to mention...
cons:
*Weather - you can't control the weather though.
* Shift time opportunities as a rookie aren't great, we bid for shifts based on Seniority. 
The payoff for sticking through it is worth it.

pros:
- Flight benefits
- 9.3% 401k match and profitsharing
- Insurance coverage is great - low cost to employee and covers most things
- Fun place to work
cons:
- Promotions are based on favoritism, not performance. The same people get recognized, while others who are performing at higher levels are overlooked
- Promotions are also based on arbitrary years of experience - employees who have been there for years but perform poorly are rewarded with promotions, while high performers with fewer years are not promoted
- If being compensated for performance is important to you, SWA is not the company for you. 
- Pay is under market, which makes it difficult to live near work in Dallas
- We are constantly told how "lucky" we are to work here. However, other companies offer much better benefits (albeit, without the flight benefits). It often feels like the culture is manufactured as a way to ignore issues. For example, when employees brought up pay issues, we were told that because we have profitsharing and 401k match we have lower pay
- No tuition reimbursement
- There is a culture of ignoring issues and being afraid of negative feedback, which leaves issues unaddressed and allows low performers to continue to grow despite being unproductive

review_title: Shiny on the outside, bleak on the inside
job_title: Senior Business Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros:
I have worked at Southwest airlines for 5.5 years. I am considered a high performer and I have been shoulder tapped several times for new roles. 
I drank the kool aide when I first joined the company but please trust me when I say, Southwest is not a place to grow your career. 

1.) Flight benefits 
2.) Really great 401K Match
3.) Some really great people but overworked
cons:
1.) Southwest lacks diversity in leadership roles and actively overlook POC for roles when considering Senior Manager and above positions. 
2.) Southwest is a place where you will have to spend 3+ years before you are promoted. Promotions are not based on hard work but rather who you know. 
3.) Working hard and creating great work does not matter at Southwest. What matters is who you suck up to. That is the only thing that will get you promoted. 
4.) The culture at SWA was really fun when I first joined 5 years ago. But since then, consultants have taken over the company and the company culture has changed for the worse. 
5.) In past years, we use to be at the top of the "Best Places to Work in America" list. We've dropped a lot. Internal Employee satisfactions scores are ABYSMAL. 
6.) For the past two years, most of us worked from home. WFH policies across the department are not all equal. 
7.) There is no work life balance. During COVID, most of us were working 12 hours a day. 
8.) Salaries are ridiculously low. On average, someone in my role at SWA makes about $115 to $130. That same role, people outside of SWA would make about $150 to $165. 
9.) We have flight benefits but no PTO to even use them. 
10.) It has become a revolving door at SWA. They only talk about who they are hiring but the company is bleeding heads and no one even mentions. Literally, I hear about 2 to 3 people have left the company on a weekly basis.

review_title: Good thing Gary is on his way out
pros: Improving pay, WFH for technology employees, mostly low stress work environment.

Customers want to feel safe and flights - all this company nonsense about how our FAs can't show good hospitality with a mask on is bogus. FAs are for safety - first and foremost. As an airline, wee can't pick and choose what safety measures we do or don't enforce. Same goes for religious exemptions on the vaccine mandate, I do not have any faith that management will be strict in vetting those.

review_title: An amazing company - but whats most important to you?
pros:
I spent several years at SWA - before covid and during. The things you hear are 100% true. I don't feel the need to cover the positives extensively as that has been done everywhere. If you have the luck of interviewing or taking a job at SWA you will not regret it - it's an absolutely amazing company with incredible People, culture, and opportunity. BUT - be aware whats most important to you out of a job & company, and recognize that may change over time, as there are some drawbacks and no place is perfect.

1. Amazing People and culture 
2. Benefits are incredible - flight perks, 401k, profit sharing, etc. 
3. You will feel apart of the mission, and what a wonderful mission.
4. Stability - no layoffs even through covid.
cons:
1. The People and culture - while listed above, this can also create a very challenging environment. My department was a bit "cliquish"and the Director tended to also have his favorites who were awarded projects and the recognition. Personal Ideas, improvements, and projects are encouraged, but only if it fits into the strategy box set by Leadership. If you tend to challenge the status quo you might find yourself a bit annoyed here and constantly having to "disagree & commit". Positivity, agreeance, and personal projects over innovation, high performance, and utility/cohesiveness. Also, poor performance tends to slip under the cracks and is never truly addressed.

2. Compensation - I have heard there have been improvements here, but SWA still falls on the lower end for many roles. They emphasize the benefits (which are great) but in a world where cash in hand is increasingly more important - their salaries miss the mark. This is also accentuated by the internal compensation philosophy and poor job architecture - which doesn't reward monetarily but by opportunity. "We are going to promote you into a Manager role because you are doing amazing, but you don't have Manager experience so we are only going to adjust your salary by 5% and put you at the absolute bottom of an already low range which you will constantly be trying to recover from". At the end of the day, it is a low-cost carrier and pay increases once you are in, are just not great. I received a 50% pay increase when I left and got a bigger raise in the first year than I got the entire time I worked at SWA..... 

3. Work-life balance - Feeling apart of a mission can be great. It can also throw WLB out of the window, and cause you to become emotionally involved when things are going great. SWA has a way of making work being heavily integrated into your life (which again is one of the pros - its alot of fun with great people who become friends/family) but it also can really stretch WLB. "if this doesn't get done, I'm letting my customers (friends/family) down". While Im sure it varies by department, my work/life balance disappeared for a while and I was working 10-12 hour days just to keep up with an unreasonable workload as I didn't want to let my customers down. Referring back to number 2. there was a real lack of awareness (potentially care) of the ridiculous workloads our Team was trying to manage.

4. Change - I almost didn't put this, as im sure People will discount me as the person who just hates change. Change is necessary, hard, and fantastic. I love progression and finding new ways of working and efficiencies. BUT - The strategy for my department was constantly changing to a point where it became difficult to get any thing done. My director had the tendency to chase the next shiny tool and buzz word, which left our Teams scrambling to make things work. Change for the sake of change, in too large of chunks, without a cohesive vision/strategy, and without the understanding of day to day tactical work is futile.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Able to trade shifts with coworkers.
Flight benefits.
Work from home since Covid.
Unlimited working hours.
cons:
You can only be sick 5 times a year. 
Coworkers charge you big money to “swap” shifts with them in order to save pto time. There’s only overtime when the company assigns it otherwise you can work 1,000 hours and it’s all at your base rate. You fly for free but that’s if you can make the flight. Your up against paying passengers so peak season, weekends, holidays, very hard to get a seat. Your calls are monitored and they pick apart everything you say or don’t say. Customers are rude, demanding, call you everything under the sun. But be nice or you’ll loose your job. Software you work in is ancient and they put money into everything else other than what would make your job easier. You repeat the same exact thing day in and day out. If you aren’t able to pay someone your entire check and give up your second child most coworkers won’t help you out by working for you. You can then only use sick time 5 times a year. If you hit 7 times your in a hearing fighting for your job. Oh you pay union dues but they don’t help you do a thing. If you notice most of the great reviews on here are people who don’t work over the phone. They also live in a fantasy world where it’s all rainbows and butterflies. Who your supervisor is determines if your job is ten times harder than the passengers make it. The only room for “growth” is if your willing to move from a call center to the airport or relocate to Dallas where all the good paying positions are that do little to no work. Health coverage is cheap but that’s because you’ll have moderate out of pocket costs especially if you need vision. If it’s too busy which is mostly everyday they can mandate you to stay late or start early usually two hours on top of your schedule. So that can mean 8-12 hr days. Your only paid extra if they force you to work. Calls are back to back to back. Not even time to take a sip of water in between. And if you block a call from coming in your in trouble. Your a robot. Everyone from the airport tells passengers to call customer service and we can’t help if they can’t help. Morale is horrible since COVID. Severely understaffed. I could go on forever but hopefully you get the point.

Last manager they hired two years ago came from repair station with a chip on his shoulder and an ax to grind with the mechanics. Not good. Forget about all the glowing reviews you read about this company. Most of them coerced, that is to say, non-contract employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement are forced to write and post positive reviews. Southwest is all smoke and mirrors. All the fun and sunshine and rainbows and daffodils you hear about at Southwest is nothing but PR department propaganda. It's all LIES.

review_title: A company that cares about people and their people's growth
pros:
Teams at SWA are built on a foundation of trust- we trust eachother and can be vulnerable and honest with your teammates. As a result, conflict fosters growth instead of fear. Management wants to see their employees bloom, and regularly offer their assistance and support. Everyone I've worked with is down-to-earth, and pretty much anything can be forgiven except for pretension and dishonesty.
Management on all levels are incredibly transparent on business developments and the state of the company and your workgroup. I'm thankful to be a part of this family, and I trust our leadership to guide us through the storms we weather.
cons: It's a large organization despite being thought of as a 'small' airline for so long. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but there can be a long ramp-up time when onboarding due to systems and operational complexity. I mean, it's a major airline after all- we must be risk averse and processes are in place for good reasons. If you're joining us, be patient at the beginning, you'll understand the in's and out's with time. Never be afraid to ask questions- we don't judge, we want to succeed!

pros: You get free flight benefits. The pay is nice.
cons: I feel like you have to sell your soul to work here. I’ve experienced lots of racism, sexism, homophobia, and even physical threats. I feel like the company doesn’t do much about it. I feel like you get in more trouble for raising concerns than actual offenders. I feel like in a high position, I get punished for reporting racism, sexism, and other things that I witness. It’s difficult knowing that people in other positions are being discriminated against like this while I have to be silent and take it. I feel like I get bullied and shut out (systemic oppression) for not keeping quiet about it. These opinions are my own and not the company’s. It’s not like you can just quit your job while you’re here. You get used to supporting your family and get stuck. There is a push for diversity and inclusion. But I feel like the diverse people who get hired want to keep their jobs. So, the same obstacles exist for minorities.

review_title: Was, and remains my dream company
pros: Amazing people, benefits, and culture. I feel genuinely cared for as a person, and I love what we do and stand for.
cons:
Some truly great leaders here, but definitely too many poor ones who either pursue their own agenda rather than the good of all, or who have deficient knowledge of how things really work (even in their own disciplines) but arrogantly think they know better. 

That said, I believe in what we do, and the good of the company far outweigh the bad.
